column5: We live in a time of absolute madness, as I'm sure most people are aware. The circular exempts small and micro enterprises with monthly sales of less than RMB 30,000 or entities making quarterly payments with sales of less than RMB 90,000, from charges of public funds. These are the Chinese educational surcharge , the local educational surcharge , the water conservancy construction fee and the cultural construction fee . In addition , eligible small and micro enterprises with less than 20 employees will be exempt from social security contributions for the employment of disabled persons . The announcement will take effect on January 1, 2015 and will last until December 21, 2017. And too many of them are still rejected by their families and pushed into the streets. We have fought to protect the rights of LGBT people and have achieved remarkable victories. But for our homeless LGBT youth, little has changed since 1969. There are at least 200,000 homeless LGBT youth on the streets of the United States. And despite our power and achievements as a movement, we have only created about 350 dedicated housing units for these 200,000 homeless LGBT youth. So , in 2014 , our children continue to suffer from the cold , to be injured and exploited in the streets , as Danny was in 1969 .

Dr Mayengbam Lalit Singh Recently, the Honorable Prime Minister of India launched a program called “Double Farmers' Income” to improve the welfare of a larger portion of Indians. The big questions people feel are (i) How could this be possible in a short time? And (ii) is it an elusive doctrine to sweep the vote bank of millions of farmers for the next legislative elections in 2019? Across India (except a few states), so many rigidities need to be resolved in order to increase the real income of farmers. These rigidities are characterized by infrastructures, structures and institutions. This article focuses on these rigidities only for Manipur which lags behind many Indian states. When it comes to infrastructure (inputs), the state finds itself backward among the backward states of India. In reviewing water infrastructure, the state has underutilized water resources despite abundant availability. For crops in the Kharif season, farmers depend on rainwater since the state is under the SE monsoon map. However, during the Rabi and Zayed seasons, the state has witnessed water scarcity. In order to curb this shortage, the government needs the construction of several control dams and the digging of boreholes in these small streams that cross the plains. During the high season, there is always a shortage of fertilizers and pesticides due to landslides on national roads. The organic farming revolution will reduce reliance on chemical fertilizers since the state has a high potential for the production of organic fertilizers and pesticides. During the post-harvest period, the state must build cold stores so that perishable crops can be stored for the off-seasons of agriculture. As far as financial support for agriculture is concerned, the banks are not integrated with the farmers. Moreover, the state government does not organize crop insurance schemes to compensate for losses due to natural calamities. My previous article on “Fundraising the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MGNREGA) with Crop and Livestock Insurance in India” postulates the model on how to compensate for the loss. The second rigid character of agriculture is that there has been no structural change over the decades. Agriculture in Manipur focuses on the production of coarse grains only which are characterized by immediate consumption. In this era of globalization, agriculture should have a close introspection of the demand and supply pattern of consumers across the world. Especially in hilly areas, the cultivation of coarse grains serves only to satisfy local consumption and not to generate profits. Farmers today report illegally growing illegal crops such as poppy in order to make huge profits. In order to avoid this, the government should emphasize the cultivation of cash crops such as yongchak (parkia speciosa), cardamom, tea, coffee, black pepper, etc. as these crops are in high demand on the international and domestic market. On the other hand, it can reduce the environmental destruction that is tracked after a short period of zoom cultivation. In lowland areas, the main crops are also coarse grains which are vulnerable to low profit. Farmers need to diversify their cash crops such as black rice, medicinal plants, oilseeds, mushrooms, etc. Additionally, farmers should engage in non-agricultural sectors where both agricultural and non-agricultural sectors can be integrated into the supply and demand calendar for their inputs and outputs. One of the institutional rigidities faced by farmers is asymmetric information about technological development in the agricultural sector. Krishi Vigyan Kendras (KVKs) have been instituted in all districts of India to bridge the information gap between farmers and agronomists. However, their work has been found to be confined to laboratories alone and their skills hardly fall within the realm of farmers' knowledge. The government should set policies for KVKs so that they are available to farmers at least once a week on alternate blocks. Another institutional rigidity we are witnessing is the financial inaccessibility of farmers to existing financial institutions (banks). In India, banks release funds for the manufacturing and service sectors, but not for the agricultural sector. Too many official procedures and rigid financial guarantees create farmers' inaccessibility to banks. Banks should therefore be advised to investigate the constructive environment in which farmers should adhere and repay loans on time. Another important institutional rigidity is the lack of marketing institutions such as marketing farms and agents who can sell these agricultural products. The government should invite local and non-local farms that can link farmers to consumers at a price determined by the market rate. The government should also have policies such as the minimum support price and the construction of cold stores so that various types of agricultural products can be available during their off season. The last most important institutional rigidity is the inability of the government to constitute an integral body which includes the body of farmers, financial institutes, KVKs, marketing farms and the government-funded research institutes mentioned above. If the integral body functions with a mutual exchange of functioning with all institutional constituents, the dream of “doubling farmers' income” can be realized. That this article can draw the attention of the Ministry of Agriculture to the realization of its ambition.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), it is estimated that more than 115 million people suffer from obesity-related problems in developing countries, where the rate of increase in overweight and obesity among children is more than 30% higher than in developed countries. Children in poor countries are more vulnerable to malnutrition. But at the same time, they are exposed to high-fat, high-sugar, high-salt and energy-dense foods, which tend to be cheaper but also of lower nutritional quality. According to some research, blood flow is increased during yawning in certain parts of the neck, jaw, and head. Cool air helps you cool the fluids in your head. Therefore, this body-fighting self-defense mechanism can perfectly help you cool down your brain temperature. A Physiology and Behavior study published in 2014 showed that yawning helps control our body's thermoregulation. Yawning helps the brain reach the optimum climate temperature.

Some human beings are totally inclined to the pursuit of virtue, and are consumed by the desire to know the Divine World, known as m'arifat, or gnosis. Others tend to get carried away with the things and pleasures of the world. There is an intermediate order of people who have an inclination for gnosis and who also have an aptitude for worldly affairs. This last category is described by Imam Razi, writing in the 12th century, as "people of the right hand or balanced people", and to these people control of the affairs of their fellows rightfully belongs. The task is never easy; mere kindness is no guarantee of success. Possession of all the virtues alone is not enough. There must be inspiration from a higher source. The element of marifat provides the necessary directions, keeping the attention on the divine light. The annual State of Education Report (ASER) launched in Islamabad on Wednesday reveals some interesting facts and figures. It notes that progress has been made in improving access to education in Pakistan, with the number of out-of-school children falling from 25 million to 22 million according to government data. However , there is still much to do . Without compromising access to school, the focus should be on improving quality. The budget allocation to education is now 3.02% of GDP, down from 2.83% last year, but still below target. The other side of the coin is that 19% of children aged 6 to 16 are still out of school. The remaining 81% who are enrolled in the 6-16 age group do not learn much either. ASER's seventh survey report also pointed out, in line with past trends, that children enrolled in private schools do better than those studying in public schools. The number of out-of-school children should be a source of concern for the whole nation and especially for the federal and provincial governments. It is quite evident that poverty is the main cause that keeps children away from schools and forces them to work to help supplement their families' incomes. The problem can be solved to a large extent if the number of public schools is increased significantly. Public schools charge little or no fees, but this is not enough to meet the needs of a growing population. The distance factor and the implication of unbearable travel costs also prohibit parents from sending their children to school. Private schools have proliferated in both urban and rural areas and cater to the needs of middle and high income segments of society, but poor families cannot afford to enroll their children in these schools. Their owners must also realize that they also have social and national obligations and offer a certain percentage of total admissions for free to students from the poorest of the poor families. There are also issues of facilities, qualifications of teaching staff and the quality of education provided and the government should, at the very least, provide training facilities for all teachers, including those employed by private schools.

OvaScience discovers, develops and markets new fertility treatments because it believes women deserve more options. Every OvaScience treatment is based on the company's proprietary technology platform that harnesses the breakthrough discovery of Egg Precursor Cells (EggPCSM) – immature egg cells found inside the protective ovarian lining. OvaScience is developing OvaTureSM, a potential next-generation IVF treatment that could help a woman produce healthy, young, fertilizable eggs without hormone injections and OvaPrimeSM, which could increase a woman's egg supply. OvaScience's AUGMENTSM treatment, a fertility option designed to improve IVF success rates, is available at select IVF clinics in certain regions of the world. OvaScience treatments are not available in the United States. For more information, visit www.ovascience.com.

The steps we are asked to take during Lent include the three traditional Lenten practices: prayer, fasting, and almsgiving. We need to make these practices a more constant part of our lives and our behavior throughout the next five and a half weeks.
